Find possible outliers in a dataset

Source: R/find_outliers.R
find_outliers.Rd

Find possible outliers in the dataset.

find_outliers(.data, var, plots = FALSE, coef = 1.5, verbose = TRUE)

Arguments

.data

The data to be analyzed. Must be a dataframe or an object of class split_factors.
var

The variable to be analyzed..
plots

If TRUE, then histograms and boxplots are shown.
coef

The multiplication coefficient. For more details see ?boxplot.stat.
verbose

If verbose = TRUE then some results are shown in the console.

Examples


library(metan)
library(dplyr)

find_outliers(data_ge2, var = PH, plots = TRUE)
#> The factors ENV GEN REP were ignored. Use 'split_factors()' if you want to perform an analysis for each level of a factor.' 
#> No outlier identified. 

data_ge2 %>%
split_factors(ENV) %>%
find_outliers(var = PH)
#> The columns ENV GEN REP where deleted. Use 'keep_factors = TRUE' to keep this columns in the grouped data. 
#> 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Level: A1 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> No outlier identified. 
#> 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Level: A2 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> No outlier identified. 
#> 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Level: A3 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Number of possible outliers: 4 
#> Lines: 7 11 14 15 
#> Proportion: 11.4%
#> Mean of the outliers: 2.438 
#> With outliers:    mean = 2.167 | CV = 10.309%
#> Without outliers: mean = 2.136 | CV = 7.377%
#> 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Level: A4 
#> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> No outlier identified.
